title: 111_s1819
content:
The Act may be cited as the "International Civil Rights Center and Museum Commemorative Coin Act". The Congress acknowledges the significance of the Greensboro sit-in in 1960, which sparked nonviolent protests against segregation across the US. Over 70,000 people participated in similar demonstrations by 1961 in over 60 cities. This led to the establishment of the International Civil Rights Center and Museum. The International Civil Rights Center and Museum, located at the site of the F.W. Woolworth's store where the sit-in movement began in 1960, will serve as an archival center and teaching facility exploring the international struggle for civil and human rights. The International Civil Rights Center and Museum, opening on February 1, 2010, commemorates the 50th anniversary of the sit-in movement, preserving the legacy of the civil rights struggle for future generations. SEC. 3. COIN SPECIFICATIONS. The Secretary of the Treasury will mint and issue up to 1,000 $1 silver coins commemorating the opening of the International Civil Rights Center and Museum. The coins will weigh 26.73 grams, have a diameter of 1.500 inches, and contain 90% silver and 10% copper. These coins will be legal tender and considered numismatic items. SEC. 4. DESIGN OF COINS. The design of coins minted under this Act shall be emblematic of the International Civil Rights Center and Museum, with inscriptions including the coin's value, year 2010, and words like "Liberty" and "In God We Trust". The design of coins minted under this Act will feature inscriptions of "Liberty", "In God We Trust", "United States of America", and "E Pluribus Unum". The design will be selected by the Secretary in consultation with the International Civil Rights Center and Museum, the Commission of Fine Arts, and reviewed by the Citizens Coinage Advisory Committee. SEC. 5. ISSUANCE OF COINS.

Coins minted under this Act shall be issued in uncirculated and proof qualities at the United States Mint at West Point, New York. The Secretary may mint coins only during the calendar year beginning on January 1, 2010. SEC. 6. SALE OF COINS. The coins issued under this Act will be sold by the Secretary at a price equal to the face value of the coins, the surcharge provided in section 7, and the cost of designing and issuing the coins. Bulk sales will be made at a reasonable discount, and prepaid orders will be accepted before the issuance of the coins. The Secretary will accept prepaid orders for coins minted under this Act at a reasonable discount. SEC. 7. SURCHARGES. Sales of coins under this Act include a $10 surcharge per coin. Surcharges go to the International Civil Rights Center and Museum for program development. The Comptroller General can audit the Museum's expenditures.
